reviewText:
When I picked this up, I honestly thought I was just going to waste a dollar. There aren't many non-sarcastic reviews on here, so I really had no idea what was in store.

This is a freaking adorable little puzzle-platformer. The puzzles are pretty easy; find the key, open the lock, find the little girl and reunite her with the ghost. The levels have slight branching as you get further in, but not to the point where you end up lost. The music is really solid; even though there's only three tracks, they're pretty enjoyable. One of them is a bit startling, being louder and faster than the other two, but still surprisingly fitting. The controls are dependable and glitch-free, which isn't always the case in an indie platformer. Hit detection is actually spot-on, a welcome change from some of the other atrocities I've picked up on coupon. Really, my only complaint thus far is that I can't spend all those pennies I've been picking up. o.0

This isn't a hardcore game, but it's definitely worth what I paid for it. It's short (you can probably beat it in under an hour), but still strangely addictive. I opened it up expecting to play a few minutes, realized half an hour had passed and came here to post. So if you have a couple spare bucks, spend them here.

reviewText:
This review was dictated, not written.

This game, I thought it wouldn't be spooky. I looked and said, oh look a cute platformer with cats, I like cats.

TRIGGER WARNINGS AHEAD.

Don't get bitten, Return the undead to the grave, stay in the light.

This game 2spooky4me. I soiled my fresh undergarments four times in the first level. During the second level you find a soul of a little girl wandering around and you have to BRING HER BODY BACK. Straight up Cronenburgian.

There are skeleton cats.

Spooky, scary, skeleton cats. They sent shivers down my spine.

There is no explanation, there is no dialogue, you start in the dark house and it goes from there. It makes Dark Souls narrative seem wordy and over explanatory.

Don't get bitten, Return the undead to the grave, stay in the light.

It doesn't make any sense, why is the cat collecting pennies? We DON'T even HAVE pennies anymore in our country, so why is the cat collecting a currency that isn't even in use? To place on the eyelids of the dead? To pay Charon to cross the river of souls?

The graphics are scary, the music spooky, and the monsters... the monsters. I think the game is taking place in a crazed cat womans house and the undead cats you return to the grave are your fallen family. You are the last of the line, like the protagonist in The Rats in the walls."

Don't get bitten

reviewText: Recommended for anyone who wants to play a short, easy-to-pick-up platformer, where you play the part of a cute little kitty collecting coins. There is no story unfortunately, but this makes it easier to just jump in and out of the action as you see fit. There are 19 levels in total which can be finished in about an hour, depending on your platforming skills. The movement and actions are very intuitive and easy to use/handle. Just dash, jump, and double-jump your way through the levels, while picking up coins, finding big keys to open locked doors, rescuing a few human souls, and avoiding or defeating enemies like zombie cats, mummy mice and flying vampire cats/bats. There are 2 ways to defeat the spooky/cutesy enemies: you can jump on them or dash into them. I haven't found a way to defeat ghost cats though, so I just tried to avoid touching them in order to sustain health points...

reviewText:
I honestly don't know what it was but I really enjoyed the game. And I'm even more of a dog person.

======OVERVIEW======
Somehow, still not sure how, I had a lot of fun playing Spooky Cats. And as I was reading other reviews, it seems like I'm not the only one. It is a short game, sure, but I guess adding more levels or some difficult puzzles/challenges would kill the momentum. I mean, I'd be more than happy if there were some more levels whether official or made by other players, but I would probably burn out of listening to spoooky cats (since they are 2 spooky 4 me... yeah, I'm a very funny person). To sum it all, the length is perfect. Other than that it's all just decent but still good nevertheless. Only the soundtrack was kinda meh" for me but not a big deal

reviewText:
tl;dr: Recommended!

Spooky Cats looks pretty simple and hacked-together at first glance, however, some elements push it to a level higher than the majority of the games in the pack of similar titles.

Positives:
excellent mechanics, spot-on controls
great level design
high cuteness level
collect pennies and reunite kids with their spirits to receive praise from mama kitty!
collected pennies don't disappear from your total, so if you die and have to redo a level there are just as many to collect each time you redo
satisfying jump on top of other cats / most dead cats/mice/etc." to eliminate them
satisfying "swoosh" rushing mechanic to eliminate things from the side
the levels are the same each time so you can learn
recommended: how to pass through them speedily if you've had to repeat them multiple times.\ncollected secrets
voteText: are yours and don't have to be re-collected\n"Great job!" and miscellaneous other prompts on screen
helpfulPercent: as well as praise from mama kitty
votesHelpful:
help to keep your excitement and mood up so you want more and more
The music can be pretty motivational
The music and other audio have separate volume sliders!
some variety in types of levels (kill ## baddies to proceed
votesTotal: cling to the wall and hop to avoid spikes and crushing walls
votesFunny:
etc.) design keeps a modicum of freshness during the gameThese gameplay elements combined and kept me playing far longer than I expected for my initial play.

Negatives:
Your number of lives count will decrement upon touching anything bad with almost no audio/visual (recoil/etc.) feedback
commentsCount: which makes it easy to lose several lives in one rapid unfortunate encounter with a spike or a baddie or multiple baddies (split-second invincibility after losing a life would solve this for the most part
column16: and an audio cue would help greatly also).\nMost of the audio sounds like it came out of a default pack
column17: making certain things (i.e. bats) not very exciting to kill\nWhen you lose a life
column18: there's no audio cue (unless it's just too quiet or similar to the rest of the sounds to be notable) to grab your attention\nThe same music tracks repeat again and again
column19: making you wish there were more aural motivational diversity after you've played for a while. When I reached that point
column20: I reduced the music volume and let it fade into my subconscious. Some players will have more tolerance than others.\nThe level design can make some spike/baddie avoidance frustrating. The spikes tend to be less forgiving
column21: because the baddies move around a tiny bit and follow the cat you're controlling to some degree
column22: whereas the spikes are non-mobile unless attached to a moving platform. For the first several levels and some of the seemingly-higher levels
column23: you'll think "this is laughably simple. I'm not a toddler! That level was short and easy!" Other levels will have you agonizing over the struggle it's taken you to reach a save point only for you to lose your last life just before reaching the save point
column24: so you'll be sent back to the beginning. That happened to me sometimes 2-3 times in a row... you'll be glad for save points at times like that. Especially if you've traveled to the end of an area just to retrieve a key for a door you needed to get through way back next to the spawn point.I got this as part of a bundle
column25: and I'm glad it was included. Rather than the shovelware many bundles include alongside their "more reputable" purchase bait

reviewText: A lot of these reviews are obviously sarcastic. Here's one that isn't. Sure, Spooky Cats looks like a flash game and it's repetitive--but it's also easy to play, fun, cute, and affordable. The music is very adequate, though limited (3 tracks looped). Because of the simple graphics, even low-grade PCs can run Spooky Cats. My laptop isn't exactly a warrior and, sadly, quite a lot of games in my Steam library don't run well on it...so it's nice to have simple games like Spooky Cats (as well as more advanced retro titles like Hotline Miami, Eversion etc) that I know I'll be able to play.\n\nAnd most importantly--I grew up on platformers, so I have a keen eye for them. Spooky Cats is the bare basics in that familiar, run-and-jump sort of way, and that's not a bad thing. The controls are very responsive and glitch free, something I can't say for a lot of indie platofrmers on Steam. Don't expect Fez, but at $3 dollars you can't really go wrong with a title like Spooky Cats. It makes a great in-between game for breaks from those more hardcore titles.

reviewText: This is easily the best indie game of 2015. Hey, it may even be the game of the year for 2015 (IMO)! The story-line is so complex yet.. Just so perfect that it's hard to even think that anyone could have possibly thought of it! The game play is easily for the hardest of hard-core gamers. It's so intricate and complicated that some people may be find it overwhelming, yet they balance it out by letting you practice your skills along the way with an endless continue system.\n\nThe horror elements of this game, don't even get me started! Let me tell you, this game is definitely one of the scariest games ever! It doesn't resort to ridiculous and needless jump-scares, it immerses you in a horrific and ominous atmosphere that will certainly keep you up for the next month or so! It's practically if Eraserhead, PT, Insidious, and Bloodborne all had a giant horror baby and put into one game. With all of this, and it's low price of $2.99 , I HIGHLY recommend that you check this game out! It will certainly be worth it!

reviewText:
Great spooky cat platformer
You are cute little cat who fight trough evil house fill with terrible cat and mouse enemies! You can kill enemies by jumping or smashing them and cats that fly with red eyes can't be killed at all. Also you are constantly collecting coins troughout game. Some levels even need you to find key or multiple keys to get pass them

There is 18 levels and 1 bonus level that will be unlocked when you collect enough coins. Don't be scare that there is so small amount of levels because they are pretty hard to get past if you want to collect everything and not loose even one life!

Pros
Double & Wall Jump
Great enemies
Controls are spot on!
Ability to smash enemies and boxes
Spooky music
Cat sounds cute when it takes damage
Focused on gameplay!
Cons
Simple menu (only level selecting menu where you can minimize  game, quit, disable sound and music)
Hardcore players would love more levels to be played in future!
In summary: This is very well made retro indie platformer that is focusing only on gameplay and not for great menu or super high visuals!

I am definitely recommending this!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=89mNoRXJDIU


Spooky Cats is instantly charming and it's appeal is obvious. A cute platformer with tight controls and solid level design that presents a perfect level of challenge. I don't think Spooky Cats will exceed anyone's expectations, but at $5 it adorably fulfill's it's promise of fun. I only have a few small complaints. While running around the mansion it's often hard to distinguish brown platforms from the brown background, when pressing switches it's difficult to tell what exactly has changed. Also, I wish the game only looped one song per level, rather than the entire soundtrack.

Pros
-cute setting and graphics
-tight controls
-well designed levels
-decent challenge

Cons
-hard to distinguish platforms
-looping soundtrack


DISCLAIMER: Review is based on approx. 1 hour of gameplay.

reviewText: Spooky Cats is a short (about forty five minutes) and simple little action platformer that starts off like a casual Halloween game, but becomes an infuriating romp with an ending that can make you chuck your controller in disappointment. It's also a far more morbid hame than it appears. The controls are tight, kinda cute sound effects, but the biggest downfalls are the limited range flashlight effect used, and the amount of spikes later that make that mode of vision far more infuriating than it has any right to be. Worth buying if you have an hour to kill, but better off waiting for a sale than paying full price.\n\nhttps://youtu.be/QnSOYgtb_j4

reviewText: A simple platformer featuring egg-shaped cats. The gimmick is that most of the screen is constantly shrouded in darkness. It's not very difficult. Most levels have a very linear approach. I beat it in under an hour, and spent more time waiting for the trading cards to come in than I did actually playing it. It isn't bug-free, and $2.99 is a bit much for this little. Though enjoyable, it lacks length and replay value. Worth it at discount, otherwise I give it a meh" out of ten."

reviewText:
It's a game about a cat. A cute little cat who makes her momma proud. Call me crazy, but because I got frustrated on some parts, I actually caught myself getting a little scared. I like horror games, I just don't like playing them.

This game gets me introduced to the genre more easily. I had plunged into the first FNaF with cheats, so that didn't help me much with getting over my fear of it (or embracing it, whichever works).

It's a good starter game into the horror genre if you're a pansy like me. Even if you're not, it's  good strategy game.
